entry.et: Middle English feste, from Anglo-French, from Latin festa, plural of festum festival, from neuter of festus solemn, festal; akin to Latin feriae holidays, fanum temple

def.dt: :an elaborate and usually abundant meal often accompanied by a ceremony or entertainment :banquet
:something that gives unusual or abundant enjoyment a visual feast
:abundance profusion an unprecedented feast of corruption, gargantuan in scale Neil Sheehan
:a periodic religious observance commemorating an event or honoring a deity, person, or thing
:to enjoy some unusual pleasure or delight
:delight gratify feasting our eyes on the scenery
:a meal eaten in common by a Christian congregation in token of brotherly love
:a gathering held to promote reconciliation and good feeling or show someone affectionate honor
